description:
Pezoporus wallicus, commonly known as the ground parrot or ground parakeet, is a small parrot species native to southeastern Australia. It is a ground-dwelling bird that inhabits coastal heathlands, woodlands, and shrublands.

The ground parrot has a distinctive green plumage with black and yellow barring, which provides camouflage among the vegetation. It has a small, hooked beak and strong legs adapted for walking and foraging on the ground. The species is known for its unique behavior of running and hiding in the undergrowth rather than flying when threatened.

Ground parrots are primarily herbivorous, feeding on a variety of grasses, sedges, and other plant matter. They are typically found in small family groups and are known for their distinctive, high-pitched calls that can be heard at dawn and dusk.

The ground parrot is considered a threatened species due to habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as predation by introduced species such as foxes and cats. Conservation efforts are focused on protecting and managing the remaining populations of this unique ground-dwelling parrot.
